transcripts.text: I want to bring up this concern I have with some of your crushing facts, right?  In that when you state just one small fact without contextualizing it, you run the risk of being counter to the generalization, which obviously my friend's fact was, right?  Agree completely.  And so I have a couple of facts that I think can help round out the picture.  One here in response to the southern strategy question.  This is a quote from Kevin Phillips, Nixon's political strategist.  It says, The more Negroes who register as Democrats in the South, the sooner the Negrophobe whites will quit the Democrats and become Republicans.  That is where the votes are.  Without prodding from blacks, the whites will backside into their old, comfortable arrangement with local Democrats.  So he's making the argument that we need the votes from the Negrophobe whites, not from the urban whites, as you suggested.  And that's coming from Nixon's campaign manager.  Secondly, data on support for the Civil Rights Act.  In the South, 7% of Democrats in Congress supported the Civil Rights Act, and 0% of Republicans did.  And in the North, 96% of Democrats and 84% of Republicans supported the Civil Rights Act.  That fact to me seems like this was not a party issue, but a
